no_coverage.title: Likely Not Covered
no_coverage.summary: Liability-only policies typically don't cover glass damage.
no_coverage.explanation: Unfortunately, if you only have liability coverage (which covers damage you cause to others), your policy will not cover damage to your own windshield. Your Options: • Pay out of pocket: Repairs cost $50-$150, replacements $200-$1,000+ • Upgrade your policy: Add comprehensive coverage for future incidents • Check for exceptions: Some states or policies have special glass provisions
nextSteps: Check if repair is cheaper than replacement

zero_deductible_state.title: Likely Fully Covered!
zero_deductible_state.summary: Your state has zero-deductible glass coverage laws.
zero_deductible_state.explanation: Good news! You live in a state with zero-deductible glass coverage laws. This means your comprehensive insurance should cover your windshield repair or replacement with no out-of-pocket cost. Important Notes: • Your insurance company cannot raise your rates for a glass claim in these states • You should still verify coverage with your insurer • Choose a shop in your insurance network to avoid billing issues Quality & Safety Reminder: • Even with full coverage, insist on OEM glass if your policy allows it or ensure high-quality aftermarket glass is used • Verify that ADAS calibration is included in the service—this is mandatory for modern vehicles with camera-based safety systems • Ask the installer to guarantee successful calibration and proper safety system function

repair_likely_covered.title: Repair Likely Fully Covered
repair_likely_covered.summary: Most insurance policies cover chip/crack repairs with no deductible.
repair_likely_covered.explanation: Most comprehensive insurance policies cover windshield repairs (not replacements) with zero deductible. This is because insurance companies save money by encouraging repair over replacement. Why This Matters: • Repairs cost $50-$150 out of pocket, but $0 with insurance • No rate increase for repair claims (typically) • Faster service (30 minutes vs 2+ hours) • Preserves your original factory windshield seal • Maintains the integrity of your vehicle's ADAS camera calibration
nextSteps: Call insurance to confirm zero-deductible repair

replacement_check_deductible.title: Likely Covered, But Check Your Deductible
replacement_check_deductible.summary: Replacement is usually covered, but you may owe your deductible.
replacement_check_deductible.explanation: If you have comprehensive coverage, your windshield replacement should be covered. However, you will likely need to pay your comprehensive deductible first. Deductible Considerations: • Low deductible ($0-$100): Claim makes sense • Medium deductible ($250-$500): Compare to out-of-pocket cost • High deductible ($500+): May be cheaper to pay yourself Rate Impact: Some insurers may raise your rates for a comprehensive claim. Ask before filing. Critical Safety Considerations: • OEM vs Aftermarket Glass: Insurance may default to cheaper aftermarket glass, which can have optical distortions that interfere with ADAS camera systems • ADAS Calibration: Modern vehicles require mandatory camera recalibration after windshield replacement. Ensure this cost ($75-$300+) is included in the quote • Quality Matters: If you don't have OEM coverage, you may need to pay the difference for manufacturer-original glass to ensure proper ADAS function

check_policy.title: Check Your Policy Details
check_policy.summary: You may have coverage, but need to verify with your insurer.
check_policy.explanation: Based on your answers, you may have glass coverage, but the details are unclear. The best step is to call your insurance company directly and ask: Key Questions to Ask: • "Do I have comprehensive coverage?" • "Does my policy cover glass damage?" • "What is my glass or comprehensive deductible?" • "Will a glass claim increase my rates?" • "Do you have a preferred shop network?" • "Do I have OEM parts coverage for glass?" • "Is ADAS calibration covered in the replacement cost?"

replacement_oem_covered.title: Covered with OEM Protection
replacement_oem_covered.summary: Your OEM coverage ensures you get manufacturer-quality glass.
replacement_oem_covered.explanation: Excellent! Your policy includes OEM parts coverage, which means your insurer is obligated to pay for manufacturer-original glass. This is the best way to ensure proper ADAS function and vehicle safety. Your Advantage: • No aftermarket compromises: You get the same glass quality as when your vehicle was new • ADAS reliability: OEM glass is specifically designed to work with your vehicle's camera-based safety systems • Optical clarity: No risk of distortions that can affect collision avoidance, lane-keeping, or automatic emergency braking What to Verify: • Confirm ADAS calibration cost is included in the replacement quote • Insist the shop uses genuine OEM glass—don't accept substitutions • Ensure the installer has proper calibration equipment for your vehicle make/model

replacement_no_oem_warning.title: Covered, But Without OEM Protection
replacement_no_oem_warning.summary: Insurance will cover it, but may default to cheaper aftermarket glass.
replacement_no_oem_warning.explanation: Your insurance will cover the replacement, but without OEM parts coverage, they will likely approve only cheaper aftermarket glass. This creates a conflict between the insurer's cost-cutting and your vehicle's safety. The Systemic Risk: • Optical distortions: Aftermarket glass can have imperfections that prevent ADAS cameras from calibrating correctly • Safety system failures: Your collision avoidance, lane-keeping, or emergency braking may not function properly • Cost pressure: Insurers may also question the cost of proper ADAS calibration ($75-$300+) Your Options: 1. Pay the difference: Upgrade to OEM glass out-of-pocket (typically $100-$400 more) 2. High-quality aftermarket: If using aftermarket, insist on premium brands and demand a guarantee of successful ADAS calibration 3. Do not skip calibration: This is a mandatory safety procedure, not optional
